revision.text:
{{Infobox song | name = Criminal | cover = Criminal cover.png | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Britney Spears]] | album = [[Femme Fatale (Britney Spears album)|Femme Fatale]] | released = {{Start date|2011|09|30}} | format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | recorded = July 2009; Maratone Studios ([[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]) | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Folk pop]] | length = {{Duration|m=3|s=45}} | label = {{Flat list| *[[Jive Records|Jive]] *[[RCA Records|RCA]]}} | writer = {{flat list| *[[Max Martin]] *[[Shellback (record producer)|Shellback]] *Tiffany Amber }} | producer = {{flat list| *Max Martin *Shellback }} | prev_title = [[I Wanna Go]] | prev_year = 2011 | next_title = [[Scream & Shout]] | next_year = 2012 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|s6b33PTbGxk|"Criminal"}}}} }}
"'''Criminal'''" is a song by American recording artist [[Britney Spears]] from her seventh studio album, ''[[Femme Fatale (Britney Spears album)|Femme Fatale]]'' (2011). The song was released as the fourth and final single from the album. "Criminal" was written and produced by [[Max Martin]] and [[Shellback (record producer)|Shellback]], with additional writing by Tiffany Amber. After Spears first listened to the song, she felt it was different and unlike anything she had heard before. She posted a snippet of it online on March 2, 2011, prior to the album's release. "Criminal" was chosen as a single by a poll on her [[Facebook]] page, as Spears explained it was a way to give back to her fans. The artwork for the single was released on September 14, 2011.
"Criminal" is a [[guitar]] and [[synth]]-driven mid-tempo pop ballad which incorporates a [[Folk music|folk]]-style flute melody. It is considered the only ballad on ''Femme Fatale'', and is less aggressive than the other songs of the album. "Criminal" is influenced by the works of [[ABBA]] and [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]. In the song, Spears sings about being in love with a [[Bad boy (archetype)|bad boy]] and [[outlaw]], and pleads to her mother to not worry about their relationship. "Criminal" received critical acclaim, with reviewers praising its organic and refreshing feel in comparison with the rest of the album. After the release of ''Femme Fatale'', the song charted on the South Korean International chart. "Criminal" has also charted in major markets such as Canada, France, Sweden, Switzerland and the United States.
The accompanying music video for the song was filmed at [[Dalston]] and [[Stoke Newington]], London. It features Spears as a woman in upper society and follows her relationship with a criminal, played by her then real-life boyfriend Jason Trawick. Prior to its release, London officials criticized Spears for shooting scenes with a replica gun and glamorizing violence. The video received a positive response from critics, with some calling it the best music video from ''Femme Fatale''. Reviewers also noted the parallels between the storyline and themes of the video with Spears's personal life.
==Background== "Criminal" was written in 2008 by Max Martin, Shellback and Tiffany Amber, and was produced by Martin and Shellback.<ref name=threeyears/><ref name=liner>{{cite AV media notes |title=Femme Fatale |others=Britney Spears|year=2011 |type=liner notes |publisher=[[Jive Records]]}}</ref> Spears told [[MTV News]] that after she first listened to the song, she felt it was different and unlike anything she had heard before.<ref name=announce>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1669925/britney-spears-next-single-criminal.jhtml|title=Britney Spears Reveals Next Single At VMAs|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|last2=Montgomery|first2=James|date=August 28, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011|publisher=MTV. [[MTV Networks]]}}</ref> In an interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', Spears spoke about Martin's productions on ''Femme Fatale'', saying, "Max played a huge role on this album and he has been there since the beginning so there is such a huge level of trust. He gets exactly what I am saying when I tell him what I want and don’t want musically".<ref>{{cite news|title=Britney Spears On Her New Album, Her Favorite Music and Working With will.i.am|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/britney-spears-on-her-new-album-her-favorite-music-and-working-with-will-i-am-20110317|date=March 17, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011|last=Knopper|first=Steve|work=[[Rolling Stone]]}}</ref> Spears recorded her vocals at Maratone Studios in [[Stockholm, Sweden]]. The track was later mixed by Serban Ghenea at MixStar Studios in [[Virginia Beach, Virginia]].<ref name=liner/> It was registered on [[Broadcast Music Incorporated]] under the legal title "In Love With a Criminal".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&page=1&keyid=11068076&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID|title=IN LOVE WITH A CRIMINAL (Legal Title)|publisher=Songs of Kobalt Music Publishing. [[Broadcast Music Incorporated]]|accessdate=August 29, 2011}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> On March 2, 2011, Spears posted on her [[Twitter]] account a link to a 17-second clip of the song, describing it as "one of [her] favorites".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1659087/britney-spears-criminal.jhtml|title=Britney Spears Teases Femme Fatale Slow Jam 'Criminal'|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|date=March 2, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011|publisher=MTV}}</ref>
On August 5, 2011, she launched a poll on her [[Facebook]] page asking fans whether her next single should be "Criminal", "[[Inside Out (Britney Spears song)|Inside Out]]" or "[[(Drop Dead) Beautiful]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1668729/will-drop-dead-beautiful-be-britney-spears-next-single.jhtml|title=Will '(Drop Dead) Beautiful' Be Britney Spears' Next Single?|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|date=August 10, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011|publisher=MTV. MTV Networks}}</ref> After the [[2011 MTV Video Music Awards]], she revealed to MTV News that "Criminal" was chosen as the fourth single.<ref name=announce/> On the British talk show ''[[This Morning (TV series)|This Morning]]'', Spears explained that the song "was chosen by the fans. It was just cool to give something back to them and see what they would appreciate."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news/britney-spears-held-song-poll-to-thank-fans_1246148|title=Britney Spears – Britney Spears Held Song Poll To Thank Fans|last=Staff|first=Contactmusic|date=September 20, 2011|accessdate=September 20, 2011|publisher=[[Contactmusic.com]]}}</ref> The "Criminal (Radio Mix)", which was included on her second remix album, ''[[B in the Mix: The Remixes Vol. 2]]'',<ref name=allmusic/> was released a single on September 30, 2011 and the song was added to the United States mainstream radio playlists on October 4, 2011.<ref name=amazon>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B005P5NVFQ/|title=Amazon.com: Criminal: Britney Spears: MP3 Downloads|date=September 30, 2011|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=September 30, 2011}}</ref><ref name=fmqb>{{cite web |url=http://www.fmqb.com/Article.asp?id=16691 |title=Available For Airplay |accessdate=September 14, 2011 |work=[[FMQB]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110925014516/http://www.fmqb.com/article.asp?id=16691 |archivedate=September 25, 2011 |df= }}</ref> The artwork for the single was released on September 14, 2011. It features Spears looking out into the distance, with her wavy hair falling on her bare back. A mysterious hooded man is also featured on the cover.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1670746/britney-spears-criminal-artwork.jhtml|title=Britney Spears' Mysterious 'Criminal' Art Hits Net|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|date=September 14, 2011|accessdate=September 14, 2011|publisher=MTV. MTV Networks}}</ref> Robbie Daw of [[Idolator (website)|Idolator]] said that "it appears as if Camp Spears hired the best [[Photoshop]] expert $15 could buy when it came to designing the art. Oh, just kidding — we love red and blue! Makes us think of sex and, uh, ice-cold criminals. Or something."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://idolator.com/6011771/britney-spears-criminal-single-cover|title=Britney Spears Has The Blues (And Reds) On Her "Criminal" Single Cover|publisher=[[Idolator (website)|Idolator]]. [[Buzz Media]]|last=Daw|first=Robbie|date=September 14, 2011|accessdate=September 15, 2011}}</ref>
==Composition== {{listen |filename = Britney Spears - Criminal.ogg |title = "Criminal" (2011) |description = A 22 second sample of the song's chorus, which features Spears telling her mother she is in love with a criminal. |pos = right |format = [[Ogg]] }} "Criminal" is a guitar-driven midtempo track which incorporates a [[Folk music|folk]]-style flute melody.<ref name=samesame>{{cite web |url=http://www.samesame.com.au/reviews/6541/CD-Britney--Femme-Fatale.htm |title=CD: Britney – Femme Fatale |last=Reporter |first=Staff |date=March 14, 2011 |accessdate=April 9, 2011 |publisher=[[Samesame.com.au]]. [[Sound Alliance]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110518073607/http://www.samesame.com.au/reviews/6541/CD-Britney--Femme-Fatale.htm |archivedate=May 18, 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name=independent/> Erin Thompson of the ''[[Seattle Weekly]]'' said the song "takes a breather from aggressive, [[wall-to-wall]] [[synths]], driven instead by a steady guitar rhythm and an oddly Asian folky-sounding flute melody.".<ref name=seattleweekly>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.seattleweekly.com/reverb/2011/10/nice_hits_is_a_reverb_1.php |title=Nice Hits!: Britney Spears' Down-Tempo 'Criminal' Is Her Own 'Papa Don't Preach' |last=Thompson |first=Erin |date=October 25, 2011 |accessdate=October 25, 2011 |work=[[Seattle Weekly]] |publisher=[[Village Voice Media]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111025012401/http://blogs.seattleweekly.com/reverb/2011/10/nice_hits_is_a_reverb_1.php |archivedate=October 25, 2011 |df= }}</ref> The radio edit changes the drums to be louder, among various other instrumental changes. It is considered the only ballad of the album.<ref name=bbffrw/> Thompson compared it to her past ballads, saying it is not "sappy" like "[[I'm Not a Girl, Not Yet a Woman]]" (2002) and not "teary-sad" like "[[Everytime]]" (2004).<ref name=seattleweekly/> "Criminal" is reminiscent of the music of [[ABBA]] and [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], and the latter's albums ''[[Ray of Light]]'' (1998) and ''[[American Life]]'' (2003), according to David Buchanan of ''[[Consequence of Sound]]'' and [[Samesame.com.au]], respectively.<ref name=samesame/><ref name=cos/> The [[Beat (music)|beat]] was compared by Keith Caufield of ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' to Madonna's "[[Don't Tell Me (Madonna song)|Don't Tell Me]]" (2000).<ref name=bbffrw/> Carl Wilson of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' said "Criminal" is "awkwardly pitched between [[Rock music|rock]] and ballad".<ref name=latimes/> The use of the flute was compared by Amy Sciarretto of PopCrush to the [[Sample (music)|sample]] of "[[The Lonely Goatherd]]" from ''[[The Sound of Music]]'' (1959) on [[Gwen Stefani]]'s "[[Wind It Up (Gwen Stefani song)|Wind It Up]]" (2006).<ref name=popcrush>{{cite web|url=http://popcrush.com/britney-spears-criminal/|title=Britney Spears, 'Criminal' – Song Review|last=Sciarretto|first=Amy|date=September 14, 2011|accessdate=September 15, 2011|publisher=PopCrush}}</ref>
In the verses, Spears sings about being in love with a bad boy and outlaw, in lyrics such as "He is a hustler / He's no good at all / He is a loser, he's a bum, bum, bum, bum" and "He is a bad boy with a tainted heart / And even I know this ain't smart". During the [[Chorus effect|chorus]], she pleads to her mother not to worry in lines such as "But mama I'm in love with a criminal" and "Mama please don't cry / I will be alright."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/138804-britney-spears-femme-fatale/|title=Britney Spears: Femme Fatale|last=Sawdey|first=Evan|date=March 29, 2011|accessdate=April 8, 2011|publisher=[[PopMatters]]. Sarah Zupko}}</ref> Andrew Leahey of ''[[The Washington Times]]'' and Erin Thompson of the ''Seattle Weekly'' compared the lyrics to those of Madonna's "[[Papa Don't Preach]]" (1986), while David Bunachan compared them to [[Coolio]]'s "Mama I'm in Love Wit' a Gangsta" (1994).<ref name=seattleweekly/><ref name=cos/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/mar/28/britneys-latest-new-life/|title=Listening Station: Britney’s latest new life|last=Leahey|first=Andrew|date=March 28, 2011|accessdate=April 9, 2011|work=[[The Washington Times]]|publisher=[[News World Media Development]]}}</ref> The words in the chorus end in 'al's syllables, as evident in lyrics such as "And this type of love isn't rational / It's physical". Keith Caufield noted that they were an unintentional nod to [[Supertramp]]'s "[[The Logical Song]]" (1979).<ref name=bbffrw/> Thompson stated that Spears's vocals are less processed than on the rest of the album, while according to Amy Sciarretto they are "heavily [[Auto-Tune|auto-tuned]] and studio-treated, [...] she delivers her lines in a monotone, robotic fashion."<ref name=seattleweekly/><ref name=popcrush/>
==Critical reception== Criminal received critical acclaim from [[music critics]]. Andy Gill of ''[[The Independent]]'' called it one of the highlights of ''Femme Fatale'', along with "[[Till the World Ends]]". Gill also said that the album sounds more programmed than natural, commenting that "indeed, such is the shock when the final track, 'Criminal', opens with a little folksong-style flute and guitar figure that one's immediate reaction is that a [[Midlake]] soundfile has been accidentally appended to Britney's running-order."<ref name=independent>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/album-britney-spears-femme-fatale-jive-2251912.html|title=Album: Britney Spears, Femme Fatale (Jive)|last=Gill|first=Andy|date=March 25, 2011|accessdate=April 8, 2011|work=[[The Independent]]}}</ref> Amy Sciarretto of PopCrush gave the song four stars, explaining that "Only Brit can make a flute sound sexy. Seriously, few pop stars can pull off a flute and Brit does it with ease."<ref name=popcrush/> Aaron-Spencer Charles of ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' said that "the verses, chorus and bridge all work perfectly for Ms. Spears, showing that she still has it from all those years ago."<ref name=metro>{{cite news|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/music/879295-rihannas-we-found-love-v-britney-spears-criminal-video-fight-club|title=Rihanna's We Found Love v Britney Spears' Criminal: Video Fight Club|last=Charles|first=Aaron-Spencer|date=October 21, 2011|accessdate=October 22, 2011|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]}}</ref> Erin Thompson of the ''Seattle Weekly'' called it her best vocal performance of the album, and added that "it has a spark and a mischievous sass to it – and these days anytime Britney shows even just a bit of her old liveliness and independence, we like it."<ref name=seattleweekly/> Rudy Klapper of [[Sputnikmusic]] commented the song "isn't exactly the progressive stylings of a [[Janelle Monáe]] [''[[sic]]''], but damn if it’s not catchy ''and'' interesting."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sputnikmusic.com/review/42509/Britney-Spears-Femme-Fatale/|title=Britney Spears – Femme Fatale|last=Klapper|first=Rudy|date=March 20, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011|publisher=[[Sputnikmusic]]. Jeremy Ferwerda}}</ref> ''[[The A.V. Club]]''{{'}}s Genevieve Koski claimed that the album "[i]s not all dance-floor narcotics", adding that "Inside Out", "Till the World Ends" and "Criminal" "add texture to the wall-to-wall synth waves and booty bass."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/britney-spears-femme-fatale,53771/|title=Britney Spears : Femme Fatale|last=Koski|first=Genevieve|date=March 29, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|publisher=The Onion, Inc.}}</ref> Robert Copsey of [[Digital Spy]] said the production of ''Femme Fatale'' is "polished, intriguing and – best of all – fun", exemplifying "Inside Out", the piano breakdown in "[[Big Fat Bass]]" and the flute in "Criminal".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/thesound/a308883/britney-spears-femme-fatale.html|title=Britney Spears: 'Femme Fatale'|last=Copsey|first=Robert|date=March 28, 2011|accessdate=April 9, 2011|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]. Hachette Filipacchi (UK) Ltd}}</ref>
No Ripcord's Gary McGinley stated that ''Femme Fatale'' "is so synth-led that hearing the simple guitar lines on Criminal and He's About To Lose Me (from the Deluxe Edition) is refreshing."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.noripcord.com/reviews/music/britney-spears/femme-fatale|title=Britney Spears : Femme Fatale|last=McGinley|first=Gary|date=April 4, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011|publisher=No Ripcord}}</ref> Natalie Shaw of the [[BBC Online]] commented that "Criminal" "with its teenage lyrics [...] on top of a fairytale flute melody and a rhythm so summery it manages to completely set itself free from the rest of the album."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/qmgw|title=Britney Spears Femme Fatale Review|last=Shaw|first=Natalie|date=March 28, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011|publisher=[[BBC Online]]. [[BBC]]}}</ref> David Buchanan of Consequence of Sound found that ''Femme Fatale'' "is entirely rescued by backtracking to ''[[Circus (Britney Spears album)|Circus]]''-style material, with [[Rihanna]]-esque 'Gasoline', and the ''Ray Of Light''-era Madonna influence in closing song 'Criminal'.<ref name=cos>{{cite web|url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2011/03/album-review-britney-spears-femme-fatale/|title=Album Review: Britney Spears – Femme Fatale|last=Buchanan|first=David|date=March 22, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011|publisher=[[Consequence of Sound]]}}</ref> Katherine St Asaph of Popdust said that as "a bad-boy track, it at least makes a bit more lyrical sense than '[[Judas (Lady Gaga song)|Judas]]' and is more vulnerable than her past few singles, which is probably a good career move."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://popdust.com/2011/08/29/britney-spears-new-single-criminal/|title=We Were All Wrong About the Next Britney Spears Single|last=St Asaph|first=Katherine|publisher=Popdust. Popdust Inc. LLC|date=September 6, 2011|accessdate=September 6, 2011}}</ref> Keith Caufield of ''Billboard'' commented that "while some of the lyrics are a teensy clunky at times – [it] is a fitting closer to a nearly-completely excellent album."<ref name=bbffrw>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/472310/britney-spears-femme-fatale-track-by-track|title=Britney Spears' 'Femme Fatale' Track By Track|last=Caufield|first=Keith|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=March 29, 2011|accessdate=September 21, 2011}}</ref> ''Los Angeles Times'' writer Carl Wilson stated that the album's momentum "flags only on the closing 'Criminal', with its formless [[Renaissance fair]] flute line and a tempo [that is] joyless".<ref name=latimes>{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Carl|date=March 28, 2011|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2011/03/album-review-femme-fatale-by-britney-spears.html|title=Album review: ‘Femme Fatale’ by Britney Spears|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=March 29, 2011}}</ref> Thomas Conner of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' considered "Criminal", along with "Inside Out", "weak mid-tempo fare" songs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.suntimes.com/music/2011/03/cd_review_britney_spears_femme.html |title=CD review: Britney Spears, 'Femme Fatale' |last=Conner |first=Thomas |date=March 23, 2011 |accessdate=April 9, 2011 |work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225020403/http://blogs.suntimes.com/music/2011/03/cd_review_britney_spears_femme.html |archivedate=February 25, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Eric R. Danton of the ''[[Hartford Courant]]'' deemed the song as "an eye-rolling homage to those oh-so-attractive bad boys that good girls lust for in spite of themselves."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.courant.com/entertainment/music/sound-check/hc-danton-britney-spears-cd-review-0320110328,0,4858126.column|title=Britney Spears' 'Femme Fatale' Is Her Best Yet|last=Danton|first=Eric R.|date=March 28, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011|work=[[Hartford Courant]]}}</ref> [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]], senior editor of [[Allmusic]], called it "a lousy song".<ref name=allmusic>{{cite news|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/b-in-the-mix-the-remixes-vol-2-r2295901|title=B in the Mix: The Remixes, Vol. 2 – Britney Spears|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|date=October 17, 2011|accessdate=October 17, 2011|publisher=[[Allmusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]]}}</ref>
==Chart performance== Following the release of ''Femme Fatale'', "Criminal" reached number fifty-one on South Korea's [[Gaon Chart|GAON]] International Chart, due to digital sales.<ref name=southkorea>{{cite web|url=http://gaonchart.co.kr/main/section/search/list.gaon?Search_str=Criminal&x=0&y=0|script-title=ko:가온차트와 함께하세요|publisher=[[Gaon Chart|GAON]]|language=Korean|accessdate=September 30, 2011}}</ref> On September 26, 2011, the song debuted at number forty on the US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Mainstream Top 40 (Pop Songs)|Pop Songs]].<ref name=uspop>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/467275/chart-highlights-maroon-5-christina-aguileras-jagger-tops-adult|title=Chart Highlights: Maroon 5, Christina Aguilera's 'Jagger' Tops Adult Pop Songs|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=September 26, 2011|accessdate=September 30, 2011}}</ref> On the chart issue of November 19, 2011, it peaked at number nineteen.<ref name=bbcurrent/> On October 5, 2011, "Criminal" entered on the [[Bubbling Under Hot 100 Singles]] chart at number twenty-one.<ref name=bubbling>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/charts/chart-search-results/singles/12004807|title=Criminal Chart History – Subscription Required|accessdate=October 17, 2011|work=Billboard}}</ref> Two weeks later, it debuted on the [[Hot 100]] at number ninety-two, due to sales of 12,000 digital units.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/charts-articles/chart-alert/chart-moves-coldplay-rebounds-on-hot-100-1005427302.story|title=Chart Moves: Coldplay Rebounds on Hot 100; Plus Album Debuts from Britney Spears, Erasure|last2=Trust|first2=Gary|last1=Caulfield|first1=Keith|date=October 20, 2011|accessdate=March 4, 2012|work=Billboard}}</ref> It then rose to a new peak of fifty-five.<ref>{{cite web|last=Grein|first=Paul|url=http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart-watch/week-ending-oct-30-2011-songs-eleven-rihanna-002531232.html|title=Week Ending Oct. 30, 2011. Songs: Eleven For Rihanna|publisher=[[Yahoo! Music]]. [[Yahoo! Inc.]]|date=November 2, 2011|accessdate=November 2, 2011}}</ref> According to [[Nielsen Soundscan]], "Criminal" has sold over 279,000 digital units in the United States as of June 2012.<ref name=bubbling/> The song also entered [[Canadian Hot 100]] at number eighty-three,<ref name=bbcurrent>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/#/song/britney-spears/criminal/24871586/|title=Britney Spears - Criminal - ''Billboard''|work=Billboard|accessdate=October 12, 2011}}</ref> reaching a new peak of sixty-three a week later and eventually peaking at sixteen.<ref name=bbcurrent/> In Brazil, the song reached number 1 on [[Billboard Brasil|''Billboard'' Hot Pop Songs]],<ref name=brazilpop>"Brasil Hot Pop & Popular Songs". Billboard Brasil (Brasil: bpp) (2): 97. January 2011.</ref> and on Hot 100 Airplay.<ref name=brazilairplay>"Brasil Hot 100 Airplay". Billboard Brasil (Brasil: bpp) (2): 80. 25 January 2012.</ref> "Criminal" also achieved moderate success in Europe, reaching the top-twenty in Slovakia, Czech Republic, Finland and France, and the top-forty in Switzerland, Sweden, Denmark, and both regions of Belgium.<ref name=europehistory>{{cite web|url=http://www.lescharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Britney+Spears&titel=Criminal&cat=s|title=Lescharts.com – Britney Spears – Criminal|language=French|publisher=[[French Singles Chart|Les classement single]]. Hung Medien|accessdate=October 3, 2011}}</ref>
==Music video==
===Development=== [[File:Stoke newington town hall 2.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Scenes of the music video were shot at Stoke Newington Town Hall.<ref name=hackney>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a341976/britney-spears-angers-mps-over-criminal-video-shoot.html|title=Britney Spears angers MPs over 'Criminal' video shoot|last=Copsey|first=Robert|publisher=Digital Spy. Hachette Filipacchi (UK) Ltd|date=2011-10-31|accessdate=2011-09-23}}</ref>]] At the 2011 MTV Video Music Awards, Spears said to MTV News that she had thought of a "really cool concept for the video, just to make it interesting. You'll have to see."<ref name=announce/> She then contacted Chris Marrs Piliero, who directed the music video for her previous single "[[I Wanna Go]]", to work with her.<ref name=trawick>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1672795/britney-spears-criminal-video-director.jhtml|title=Britney Spears Boyfriend's 'Criminal' Role 'A Challenge'|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|last2=White Wolf|first2=Vanessa|date=October 19, 2011|accessdate=October 19, 2011|publisher=MTV. MTV Networks}}</ref> She told him the basic story she had planned, which he described as a "[[fairy-tale]], sweet, knight-in-shining-armor feel to it. I said let's take that and make the fairy tale badass."<ref name=marrsusa>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/story/2011-10-24/britney-spears-jason-trawick-criminal-video/50891194/1|title=Spears, 'Criminal' boyfriend craft a 'sensual' fairy tale|work=[[USA Today]]|first=Ann|last=Oldenburg|date=October 25, 2011|accessdate=October 25, 2011}}</ref> Spears also wanted her real-life boyfriend Jason Trawick to play the criminal. Marrs Piliero was initially hesitant to cast Trawick feeling that a professional actor would do a better job, but did not talk to Spears about it.<ref name=trawick/> He told ''[[USA Today]]'', "When you're doing nudity, I don't think it was at the top of Britney's list to bring in some random guy while her boyfriend watches. [...] We definitely wanted to make some passionate, steamy scenes, but we also wanted it to be intensely beautiful. We didn't want to go for raunchy. We wanted it to be sensual and steamy."<ref name=marrsusa/> On September 6, 2011, Spears announced through her Twitter account that she had decided to shoot the video "in the streets of merry old [[England]] when I get there."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalfm.com/artists/britney-spears/news/teases-new-single-music-video/|title=Britney Spears Teases New Music Video|last=Staff|first=Capital FM|publisher=[[The Capital FM Network]]. [[Global Radio]]|date=September 6, 2011|accessdate=September 6, 2011}}</ref> In an interview with [[AOL]], she explained, "I've never shot on location out of the country of America for a video. So, it should be very interesting. It was partly my idea ... to see if it could to happen, and they were like, 'Yeah, it's a great idea,' so we did it."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1670948/britney-spears-criminal-music-video-set.jhtml|title=Britney Spears Armed And Dangerous In 'Criminal' Pics|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|date=September 19, 2011|accessdate=September 19, 2011|publisher=MTV. MTV Networks}}</ref>
===Synopsis=== [[File:Britney Criminal video.png|thumb|300px|right|Spears and her boyfriend Jason Trawick kissing as his house is being shot.]] The video begins at a formal party in which Spears seems to be looking for someone. The opening shot of her was inspired by the scene of [[Jennifer Love Hewitt]] walking into the party in ''[[Can't Hardly Wait]]'' (1998). Her boyfriend (Bradshaw) talks with two people next to her.<ref name=spysynopsis>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a346098/britney-spears-holds-up-convenience-store-in-criminal-video-watch.html|title=Britney Spears holds up convenience store in 'Criminal' video: Watch|last=Goodacre|first=Kate|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011|publisher=Digital Spy. Hachette Filipacchi (UK) Ltd}}</ref> He persuades her to smile to avoid embarrassment from the guests then verbally abuses her and grabs her face, after which she leaves to the restroom, where she wipes away a tear and puts on her fragrance [[Radiance (fragrance)|Radiance]]. She comes back to the party and catches her boyfriend flirting with another woman; Spears tells her "So you're not working the street corner tonight I see?", making her boyfriend angry.<ref name=huff/> He apologizes to the other woman for his girlfriend's remark then grabs Spears by the arm and carries her outside the building. After he slaps her, one of the waiters of the party (Trawick) wearing a leather jacket punches her boyfriend several times.<ref name=spysynopsis/> The waiter asks Spears if she is okay, and after she kicks her boyfriend in the crotch goodbye, she replies "Now I'm okay."<ref name=nymag/> She and the waiter climb on his motorcycle and leave the scene. When they get to his house, it is revealed by a newspaper that he is a criminal. She opens one of the lockers in his house and finds a gun, after which the couple kisses. This is followed by scenes of them having sex.
The next morning, the criminal brings Spears breakfast to the bed and kisses her on the forehead. He has several tattoos in his body, including one on his chest that reads "R.I.P. Goose", a reference to the film ''[[Top Gun]]'' (1986).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dose.ca/music/Britney+Spears+Jason+Trawick+Debut+Criminal+Video+Really+Tattoos/5567497/story.html?cid=dose_nav_drop|title=Britney Spears and Jason Trawick Debut 'Criminal' Video, Really Bad Tattoos|work=[[Dose (magazine)|Dose]]|publisher=[[Postmedia Network]]|date=October 18, 2011|first=Leah|last=Collins|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref> They go to a convenience store where she steals vanilla candles and points the gun to the employee; the criminal takes money out of the cash register and they escape by stealing a [[Citroën DS3]].<ref name=idolatormv/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.landingpage.citroen.com/ |date=22 October 2011 |archivedate=22 October 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62d9GPfE5?url=http://www.landingpage.citroen.com/ |title=Citroën Landing Page |publisher=[[Citroën]] |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The robbery is caught by the security cameras, and pictures of the couple appear on the local news. There are scenes of them having sex in the shower. As they change clothes, several policemen then appear outside the criminal's house; they start shooting it with [[Heckler & Koch MP5]]'s as Spears and the man embrace, kissing passionately. The policemen then enter the house, and one of them confirms that the couple escaped. The video ends with Spears and the criminal escaping on the motorcycle as the credits roll. One of them reads "No vanilla candles were harmed in the making of this music video." The video also includes intercut scenes of Spears performing dance moves similar to [[Vogue (dance)|voguing]].<ref name=idolatormv/>
===UK controversy=== [[File:Diane Abbott, New Statesman hustings, trimmed.jpg|thumb|150px|left|[[Hackney North and Stoke Newington (UK Parliament constituency)|Hackney]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[Diane Abbott]] said that Spears contributed to the glamorization of guns with the video.<ref name=hackney/>]] After pictures of Spears and Trawick carrying replica guns on set surfaced online, the [[Hackney London Borough Council]] criticized her for "promoting gun violence", since the area had been badly affected by the [[2011 England riots]]. The Council told ''[[London Tonight]]'' that they had not agreed to the use of replica guns at Stoke Newington Town Hall, and that they would be raising the matter with the production company. Councillor Ian Rathbone added that Spears should apologize and make a sizeable donation to a Hackney charity "for the rudeness and damage she's done to this community." When asked if she thought the council was overreacting, [[Hackney North and Stoke Newington (UK Parliament constituency)|Hackney]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[Diane Abbott]] insisted: "It is only a music video but it's images like this, with popstars glamorising gangs, which means that some young people... get drawn in. Britney should really know better."<ref name=hackney/> Rae Alexandra of the ''[[SF Weekly]]'' explained that the United Kingdom "is not a place that readily embraces guns. Rather, it's a place where guns are rare, gun licensing is tightly controlled, and the entire establishment has been in a panic about gun use on its streets for the last three years."<ref name=sfweekly>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.sfweekly.com/shookdown/2011/10/britney_and_rihanna_debut_new.php|title=Britney and Rihanna Debut New Videos – and Anti-English Sentiments|last=Alexandra|first=Rae|date=October 25, 2011|accessdate=October 21, 2011|work=[[SF Weekly]]|publisher=Village Voice Media}}</ref> On September 26, 2011, Spears' representatives released a statement to MTV News saying, "The video is a fantasy story featuring Britney's boyfriend, Jason Trawick, which literally plays out the lyrics of a song written three years before the riots ever happened."<ref name=threeyears>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1671542/britney-spears-criminal-video-gun-criticism-response.jhtml|title=Britney Spears Responds To 'Criminal' Video Controversy|last=Montgomery|first=James|date=September 26, 2011|accessdate=September 30, 2011|publisher=MTV. MTV Networks}}</ref> The production company apologized to the Council before the release of the video.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2050440/Britney-Spears-Criminal-music-video-Boyfriend-Jason-Trawick-cast-sex-scene-lover.html|title=True Romance: Britney Spears' casts boyfriend Jason as her lover for steamy sex scene in her music video|work=[[Daily Mail]]|first=Andrea|last=Magrath|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref> Marrs Piliero stated about the controversy, <blockquote> "Holding the gun became a controversial thing 'cause we filmed it in London, and they don't have a lot of gun use out there. That doesn't mean that there's no gun use, so I did find it really interesting. For me, the thing is, it blew me away that members of [the British] Parliament were speaking about this. One, because it's a music video, and two, because don't you guys have television shows out there that show crime? It's really strange to me. I don't understand why pop stars are put on such a high pedestal over other celebrities. Why do members of Parliament feel that they need to scrutinize her for having a gun, and 'She's in the public,' and 'She should know better,' and 'She's a role model,' but what about every other celebrity out there? What about every other actor? That's very strange to me. I was really surprised at how much the gun use was scrutinized. [Trawick plays] a professional criminal, so it makes sense he has a gun. We shouldn't censor ourselves."<ref name=pilierogun>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1672848/britney-spears-criminal-director-gun.jhtml|title=Britney Spears' 'Criminal' Director Talks Gun Controversy|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|last2=White Wolf|first2=Vanessa|date=October 20, 2011|accessdate=October 25, 2011|publisher=MTV. MTV Networks}}</ref> </blockquote>
===Release and reception=== {{double image|right|Alfred Hitchcock by Jack Mitchell.jpg|182|Guy Ritchie.jpg|180|The video was compared to films by [[Alfred Hitchcock]] (''left'') and [[Guy Ritchie]] (''right'').<ref name=idolatormv/><ref name=rsmr/><ref name=aolmv/>}} The video was ranked at number ten on a list of the ten most controversial music videos in pop music by AOL on September 29, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.music.aol.com/2011/09/29/controversial-music-videos/?ncid=webmail2|title=Top 10 Most Controversial Music Videos in Pop|last=Gayles|first=Contessa|date=September 29, 2011|accessdate=October 3, 2011|publisher=[[AOL]]}}</ref> Spears announced through her Twitter account on October 13, 2011, that the video would be released the following week.<ref name=release>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1479725/20031013/spears_britney.jhtml|title=When Madonna Co-Stars In Britney Video, Opposites Attract – Music, Celebrity, Artist News | MTV|last=Vineyard|first=Jennifer|date=2003-10-13|publisher=MTV. MTV Networks|accessdate=2010-10-15}}</ref> On October 17, 2011, she posted five [[GIF]] files with scenes from the video on her [[Tumblr]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://idolator.com/6046952/britney-spears-criminal-video-in-gif|title=Preview Britney Spears’ "Criminal" Video In GIF Form|publisher=Idolator. Buzz Media|last=Bain|first=Becky|date=October 17, 2011|accessdate=October 17, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsroom.mtv.com/2011/10/17/britney-spears-criminal-video-gifs-wall-5-things-we-learn/|title=What Do We Learn About Britney's 'Criminal' Video From Those GIFs?|publisher=MTV Newsroom. MTV Networks|date=October 17, 2011|first=Sterling|last=Wong|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref> The video was released the same day on the [[iTunes Store]]; it reached the top position on its chart within minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/465735/britney-spears-releases-criminal-video-on-itunes|title=Britney Spears Releases 'Criminal' Video on iTunes|work=Billboard|date=October 18, 2011|first=David|last=Greenwald|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cambio.com/2011/10/17/britney-spears-criminal-music-video-races-up-itunes-chart-wit/|title=Britney Spears' "Criminal" Music Video Races Up iTunes Chart Within Minutes|date=October 17, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011|publisher=Cambio. AOL|last=Hiser|first=Lisa}}</ref> Becky Bain of Idolator called it "an epic mini-movie, full of romance, intrigue [...] [with] a whole lot of unnecessary [[Public display of affection|PDA]] between Brit and her beau. It was full of passion, joy and just a little touch of madness — just like its star." Bain also noted several influences, such as [[Alfred Hitchcock]] films and the music videos for Spears' "[[Toxic (song)|Toxic]]" (2004) and [[Green Day]]’s "[[21 Guns (song)|21 Guns]]" (2009).<ref name=idolatormv>{{cite web|url=http://idolator.com/6047852/britney-spears-criminal-video-premiere|title=Britney Spears' 'Criminal' Video: Sex! Violence! Bad Tattoos!|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011|publisher=Idolator. Buzz Media|last=Bain|first=Becky}}</ref> A writer for ''Rolling Stone'' also compared it to a Hitchcock film and deemed the opening scene as "a tribute to [[Old Hollywood]]". The reviewer found the scenes of physical abuse "surprising" and called the acting "stiff", but said that "from there on out, we're in the usual comfort zone of a Britney video – sexy dancing, sexy vamping – with the added bonus of gratuitous PDA between the pop star and her real-life boyfriend."<ref name=rsmr>{{cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/videos/new-and-hot/britney-spears-criminal-20111018|title=Video: 'Criminal'|work=Rolling Stone|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref>
''[[USA Today]]''{{'}}s Ann Oldenburg described the video as sexy and "pretty personal."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2011/10/britney-spears-boyfriend-sexy-in-criminal-video/1|title=Britney Spears, boyfriend sexy in 'Criminal' video|work=USA Today|first=Ann|last=Oldenburg|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref> Kenneth Partridge of AOL commented, "Packed with sex, violence and questionable acting, the new Britney Spears video, 'Criminal,' has all the trappings of a [[midnight movie]]."<ref name=aolmv>{{cite web|url=http://blog.music.aol.com/2011/10/18/britney-spears-criminal-video/|title=Britney Spears Gets 'Criminal' in New Video |first=Partridge|last=Kenneth|publisher=AOL Music Blog. AOL|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref> A reporter from the American edition of ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' said: "We can't honestly remember the last time Britney Spears looked so gorgeous in a music video" and deemed it as the best video from ''Femme Fatale''.<ref name=huff>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/10/18/britney-spears-premieres-criminal_n_1017318.html|title=Britney Spears Premieres New Steamy Video For 'Criminal' (Video)|last=Reporter|first=AOL|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|publisher=AOL|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref> Erin Strecker ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' also called it the best video of the album, and highlighted Spears' look, the ending scene and the "fun story".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2011/10/18/britney-spears-criminal-video/|title=Britney Spears and her real-life boyfriend go Bonnie and Clyde in video for new single ‘Criminal’: Watch here!|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|first=Erin|last=Strecker|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref> Katherine St Asaph of Popdust said it is "probably the best video of the ''Femme Fatale'' era."<ref name=pdmv/> Tom Townshend of [[MSN]] stated that although the video was not appropriate for Spears' younger fans, "[it] is actually rather compelling and feels more like a short film rather than a pop starlet's music video."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://music.uk.msn.com/blog/editor-blogpost.aspx?post=34699d9b-863d-4cc0-bb96-01cdc1017f37|title=Britney Spears' new music video: Criminal|first=Townshend|last=Tom|publisher=MSN Music Blog UK. [[MSN]]|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref> A writer for [[VH1]] said that part of the reason the video works is the comic sensibility between Spears and Marrs Piliero, explaining that "[it] point[s] to one of Spears's greatest talents: giving the impression that although she takes her career extremely seriously, she nevertheless doesn't take it too seriously." The critic summarized the review by saying that the video is "entertaining [as] a bad-girl adventure story, and her role here is essentially that of a (wait for it) [[femme fatale]]."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blog.vh1.com/2011-10-20/britney-spears-makes-news-in-criminal/|title=Britney Spears Makes The News, Makes Out In "Criminal"|publisher=VH1. MTV Networks|first=VH1|last=Reporter|date=October 20, 2011|accessdate=October 25, 2011}}</ref>
Critics also commented on the Hackney controversy.<ref name=nymag/> Sarah Dean of the UK edition of ''The Huffington Post'' said: "If having a blonde, leather-clad superstar brandishing a gun at a shop owner's face isn't glamourising violence, I'm not sure what is" and added that, in essence, the video "seems more like an opportunity for her to live out her sexual fantasies than anything beneficial to music fans."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2011/10/18/britney-spears-criminal_n_1017046.html|title=Britney Spears 'Criminal' Video – More Proof Pop Stars Shouldn't Act|first=Sarah|last=Dean|work=The Huffington Post|publisher=AOL|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref> Amanda Dobbins of ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' stated that "After viewing the final product, we're guessing [the local officials] probably won't be down with the shower sex, the regular sex, the domestic abuse, the armed robbery, or any of Britney's other questionable activities, either."<ref name=nymag>{{cite news|url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2011/10/britney_criminal_video.html|title='Criminal' Video: Britney Goes Bonnie & Clyde on London|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|publisher=New York Media, LLC|date=October 18, 2011|first=Amanda|last=Dobbins|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref> Katherine St Asaph of Popdust joked about the situation, saying, "Britney Spears’ video for 'Criminal' is out, and ''gang recruitment is already up 200% since 8 a.m.!'' This has not happened."<ref name=pdmv>{{cite web|url=http://popdust.com/2011/10/18/britney-spears-criminal-video/|title=Watch Britney Spears' 'Criminal' Video, Wonder What the Violence Fuss Was About|first=Katherine|last=St Asaph|publisher=Popdust. Popdust LLC|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref> Marianne Garvey of the UK website of [[E! Online]] said, "With the 'fantasy' getting so hot and heavy and Britney stripping down to nothing, the guns are the last thing you notice."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.eonline.com/news/britney_spears_controversial_criminal/270062|title=Britney Spears' Controversial "Criminal" Video—How Steamy Is It?|publisher=[[E! Online]]. [[E!]]|first=Marianne|last=Garvey|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref>
===Themes and analysis=== [[File:Rihanna, LOUD Tour, Belfast cropped 2.jpg|thumb|165px|left|The plot and themes of the video received comparisons to that of [[Rihanna]]'s "[[We Found Love (music video)|We Found Love]]", which premiered two days after "Criminal".<ref name=pdrihanna/>]] Alyssa Rosenberg of [[ThinkProgress]] said that although it is common to see pop stars being assaulted by men in their videos —exemplifying [[Rihanna]]'s "[[Man Down (song)|Man Down]]"— the public is aware of Spears's vulnerability, explaining that "we believe she really would choose a guy who would do something like this to her." Rosenberg also stated even though her bad behaviour once she leaves her boyfriend is not directed at him, the fact that he treated her badly is a form of narrative permission for her to rob a store and have sex with the criminal. She also commented that the same narrative works on her previous video with Marrs Piliero for "I Wanna Go".<ref name=think>{{cite web|url=http://thinkprogress.org/alyssa/2011/10/19/346770/the-vulnerabilities-of-britney-spears/|title=The Vulnerabilities Of Britney Spears|first=Rosenberg|last=Alyssa|publisher=[[ThinkProgress]]. [[Center for American Progress]]|date=October 21, 2011|accessdate=October 26, 2011}}</ref> The video received comparisons to Rihanna's "[[We Found Love]]", which was released two days after "Criminal", on October 19, 2011.<ref name=sfweekly/><ref name=pdrihanna/> Among the similarities, critics noted that they were both filmed in the United Kingdom and arose controversy in the country; both contain scenes of sex, violence and crime; both feature bad boy archetypes and both evoke the personal lives of the artists.<ref name=pdrihanna>{{cite web|url=http://popdust.com/2011/10/24/rihanna-britney-spears-personal-lives-videos/|title=Britney Spears, Rihanna, And the Videos Ripped From the Rumors|first=Katherine|last=St Asaph|publisher=Popdust. Popdust LLC|date=October 24, 2011|accessdate=October 25, 2011}}</ref> Katherine St Asaph found the opening line of Spears's boyfriend ("Would you try smiling ''just once''?") a subtle dig at the press. She explained that there is a tendency among writers and spectators to call "her every smile plastered on or [[Conservatorship|conservator]]-mandated", and that the fact the line is delivered by her abusive boyfriend only makes it more evident. According to her, that there are two contradictory ways to analyze the relationship between Spears and Trawick as the criminal: it could be seen as him luring her into her life, but Spears is the one that kisses him and she is the first to pull the gun.<ref name=pdrihanna/>
St Asaph explained that the only interpretation of the video lies on the opinion of each viewer about Spears's personal life, and how active a role each person imagines she plays in it. It was noted by St Asaph that although most pop stars release videos that draw from their personal lives, they do not make the viewer uncomfortable. The same cannot be said for Spears and Rihanna, and it does not matter if they themselves have moved on from past situations, because the discussion around them has not. St Asaph also expressed that neither Spears or Rihanna said much about the parallels to their lives, but that they do not need to: their videos are much more effective than anything they could reveal in an interview.<ref name=pdrihanna/> Rae Alexandra of the ''SF Weekly'' also compared it to "We Found Love", saying that both videos feature an [[anti-British sentiment]]. She wrote that all the villains in the video – her boyfriend and the policemen – are British, whereas her savior in the video is an American criminal. Alexandra noted that Spears and Rihanna chose to films their "grittiest videos" in a country with a lower [[crime rate]] than the United States, that is also so against guns that politicians felt the need to talk about it. According to her, the videos continue with a [[xenophobic]] portrayal of British people as villains by American [[popular culture|pop culture]].<ref name=sfweekly/>

"'''Dad joke'''" is a pejorative term used to describe a [[wikt:corny|corny]] or predictable [[joke]], typically a [[pun]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/fathers-day-in-praise-of-dad-jokes-20150903-gjee1r.html|title=Father's Day: In praise of dad jokes|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref> Generally inoffensive, dad jokes are traditionally told by [[father]]s among family, either with sincere humorous intent, or to intentionally provoke a negative reaction to its "[[Dag (subculture)|dagginess]]". One of the most common "dad jokes" goes as follows: A child will say to the dad, "I'm hungry," to which the dad will reply, "Hi, Hungry, I'm Dad." Many dad jokes may be considered [[Anti-humor|anti-jokes]], deriving humour from an intentionally unfunny punchline. The term has spread into general use, receiving mentions in Australian quiz show ''[[Spicks and Specks (TV series)|Spicks and Specks]]'',<ref>{{Citation|last=zombieshoes76|title=Spicks & Specks- Dad Jokes|date=2009-08-30|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5lKVBlARYEg|accessdate=2016-03-02}}</ref> and American sitcom ''[[How I Met Your Mother]]''.<ref>{{Citation|last=Fryman|first=Pamela|title=Not a Father's Day|date=2008-11-10|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1256189/synopsis|accessdate=2016-03-02}}</ref>
